meta.title: Frames: Film Photography App for Analog Shots & Metadata
meta.description: Film photography app for analog shooters. Track camera settings, organize rolls, and embed EXIF metadata into scanned images. Free trial for iPhone & Mac.

company.description: Frames is an iOS and macOS app that helps film photographers log, organize, and track their analogue photography process.

hero.heading_seo: Frames Film Photography App: Notes and Metadata for Analog Photography
hero.heading:
The essential photography notebook,
designed for analog shooters.
hero.paragraph1: Shooting film is a deliberate, intentional process, but keeping track of your settings shouldn't slow you down. Frames is built specifically for analog photographers who want the precision of digital metadata without sacrificing the tactile joy of film. Whether you're testing new film stocks, perfecting your exposure technique, or simply want to remember what worked on that perfect shot, Frames captures every detail exactly when and where you need it.
hero.paragraph2: Unlike generic note-taking apps or paper notebooks, Frames understands film photography. It knows your gear, speaks your language with proper f-stops and shutter speeds, and organizes everything by roll and frame. When your scans come back, you can embed all your shooting data directly into the image files, creating a complete archive that works seamlessly with Lightroom, Bridge, and every other tool in your workflow. Your analog process gets digital precision, without the compromises.
hero.paragraph3: Thousands of film photographers trust Frames to be their shooting companion, from weekend hobbyists to professional archive builders. No ads, no tracking, no subscriptions to services you don't need. Just a beautifully crafted tool that respects your creative process and keeps your data private and portable. Start your free trial and see why film shooters are ditching their notebooks for good.

hero.alt: Frames film photography app and analog photography app for Mac and iPhone, designed to log film rolls, manage metadata, and archive analog photos.

hero_mobile.alt: Frames film photography app and analog photography app for Mac and iPhone, designed to log film rolls, manage metadata, and archive analog photos.

preview1.heading: Quick Shot Logging
preview1.caption: Log your shots instantly with intuitive dials for shutter speed and aperture. The streamlined interface lets you capture exposure settings in seconds without interrupting your creative flow, ensuring every frame's details are preserved for later reference.
preview1.alt: Film camera shot recorder with shutter speed dial and aperture selector for quickly logging exposure settings while shooting analog photography.

preview2.heading: Comprehensive Metadata
preview2.caption: Track every detail that matters to your photography. Record camera gear, film stock, aperture, focal length, shutter speed, ISO, flash settings, GPS location, and custom notes. Keep comprehensive records that help you learn and improve with each roll you shoot.
preview2.alt: Complete film metadata tracking fields: camera gear, film stock, aperture, focal length, shutter speed, ISO, flash settings, and GPS location data.

preview3.heading: Film Roll Archive
preview3.caption: Browse your complete film archive with every roll beautifully organized. See roll names, shooting dates, and film stock at a glance. Search, filter, and revisit past sessions to analyze your work, track your progress, and rediscover forgotten frames.
preview3.alt: Film roll archive library displaying organized shooting sessions with roll names, capture dates, and film stock details for easy reference and review.

preview4.heading: Equipment Catalog
preview4.caption: Build a complete digital catalog of your photography gear. Add cameras, lenses, filters, and accessories with detailed specifications. Having your equipment organized means faster shooting prep and consistent metadata across all your film rolls.
preview4.alt: Photography equipment management interface for cataloging and organizing film cameras, lenses, filters, and accessories in your shooting workflow.

preview5.heading: Portable Data Export
preview5.caption: Export your shooting data as portable JSON-based .frames files. Back up your records, share them across devices, or migrate between iPhone and Mac seamlessly. Your data stays accessible and future-proof, giving you complete ownership and control.
preview5.alt: JSON-based .frames file format icon for exporting film photography data, enabling backup, cross-platform sharing, and metadata transfer between devices.

preview6.heading: Universal Compatibility
preview6.caption: Your embedded metadata works everywhere you need it. Apple Finder, Flickr, Google Photos, Adobe Lightroom, Adobe Bridge, and Darktable all recognize and display your film shooting data, creating a unified workflow from analog capture to digital archive.
preview6.alt: Photography software compatibility: Apple Finder, Flickr, Google Photos, Adobe Lightroom, Adobe Bridge, and Darktable supporting embedded film metadata.

reviews.heading: What Users Say About Our Film Photography App

review1.title: Reliable Film Photography App That Transfers Shooting Data
review1.quote: Easy to use, reliable, and fairly priced app that transfers shooting data, including geolocation, into scanned negatives' EXIF. The developer listens to feedback and keeps improving. Excellent!

review2.title: Perfect App for Logging Film Shots and Replacing Notebooks
review2.quote: As a home-developing film photographer, I love how Frames lets me log every shot without the hassle of notebooks. It is the perfect and practical solution. Went Pro and never looked back!

review3.title: Track Exposure and Location Data Easily When Shooting Film
review3.quote: Great for recording exposure and location when shooting film, ideal for analyzing settings or keeping EXIF-style data. The developer fixed a bug within a day. Highly recommended!

review4.title: Frames Keeps Film Photographers Organized and Mindful
review4.quote: Getting back into film, I missed having metadata until I found Frames. It replaces paper notes, helps me stay organized, and keeps me mindful when shooting. A must-have for film photographers!

review5.title: Clean, Simple, and the Best Film Notes App I’ve Used
review5.quote: You can tell the developer uses the app too. Every small detail feels intentional, and the interface is clean and simple. Everything works smoothly. Easily the best film notes app available!

review6.title: Fast, Private, and Feature-Rich Analog Photography App
review6.quote: The best analog photography app I’ve used so far. It is simple, fast, and includes all the features I really need for organizing my work. No ads, no tracking, and privacy is a major plus.

review7.title: Elegant and Well-Crafted App for Managing Film Rolls
review7.quote: The app is simple and does exactly what it should. I love being able to name my current film rolls since I sometimes forget which camera I used. The UI is clean, elegant, and well-crafted.

review8.title: Indispensable for film photography enthusiasts
review8.quote: Essential tool for film photographers. Perfect for adding metadata to scans: aperture, shutter speed, filters, location, film stock. Regular updates, great support. Highly recommended.

review9.title: Indispensable for film photography enthusiasts
review9.quote: This is precisely the tool I wished existed for my film photography workflow. All the essential tracking features are present, the customization is wonderful, and I love that I can add my own film stocks to the database. Absolutely delighted.

meta.title: How to Log and Embed Film Photography Metadata with Frames
meta.description: Learn how to use Frames to log film camera settings, organize your rolls, and embed EXIF metadata into your scanned images across iPhone and Mac.

howto1.heading: 1. Create a new roll
howto1.description: Open Frames on your iPhone and tap the icon in the bottom-right corner to start a new roll. Add your film camera, lenses, and choose your film stock. The ISO is set to box speed by default, but you can adjust it to match your light meter. This is where your film photography workflow begins.

howto2.heading: 2. Log Each Shot as You Go
howto2.description: As you shoot film, record camera settings for each frame: aperture, shutter speed, focal length, flash, creative notes, and more. Geolocation, place names, and timestamps are automatically captured to support a precise analog photography log. You can use the default slider-based controls or switch to a classic form view via the top-right menu.

howto3.heading: 3. Export your Data
howto3.description: Once your roll is finished and all shots are logged, export the data as a .frames file. Send it to your Mac using AirDrop, email, or any method you prefer. This file contains all your recorded film shot metadata for later use with your scans.

howto4.heading: 4. Load your Data
howto4.description: After your film is developed and scanned, open the .frames file on your Mac. Simply double-click it or drag it into the Frames app for macOS. Your recorded frames will load instantly, ready to be paired with your scanned photo files.

howto5.heading: 5. Associate Data with Photos
howto5.description: Browse your logged shots using list, grid, or full view, and begin associating each scan with its frame data. JPEG, TIFF and DNG images are currently supported, with CR2 and NEF coming soon. This step links your analog photos with detailed EXIF metadata, preserving the context of every shot.

howto6.heading: 6. Export your Photos
howto6.description: Once everything is matched, export your updated images. Metadata is embedded directly into each photo file, ensuring it stays visible across devices, editing tools, and platforms like Flickr. Your film photography gets the searchable, organized benefits of digital, without losing its soul.

question1.question: What metadata can I record?
question1.answer: Frames lets you log detailed information for every shot, including camera, lens, filters, frame number, focal length, aperture, shutter speed, ISO, metering mode, film stock, flash, GPS location, timestamps, and custom notes, ensuring you never lose track of important analog photography details.

question2.question: Which image formats are supported?
question2.answer: Frames supports JPEG, TIFF, and DNG formats, allowing you to embed your recorded metadata directly into scanned analog photos for seamless organization and workflow across your devices.

question3.question: Is Frames on Android or Windows?
question3.answer: Frames is currently available for iPhone and macOS. Versions for Android and Windows are planned for 2026, and in the meantime, you can share and manage your data via .frames file exports.

question4.question: Which shutter speeds and apertures are supported?
question4.answer: Frames provides default sequences that cover most lenses and cameras, and you can also define custom sequences for your gear, making it compatible with any shutter speed or aperture values.

question5.question: Can I log tripods or accessories?
question5.answer: Yes, you can record tripods, flashes, and other accessories using the custom notes field available for each shot. This flexible approach lets you document any equipment or shooting details that matter to your workflow, from tripod models to remote releases and light modifiers.

question6.question: Can I sync my data between iPhone and Mac?
question6.answer: Yes, you can seamlessly transfer your film photography data between iPhone and Mac using .frames file exports. Simply export your rolls from one device and import them on another. While automatic cloud sync isn't currently available to maintain your privacy and data ownership, the .frames format makes manual syncing quick and straightforward.

question7.question: Does Frames work offline?
question7.answer: Absolutely. Frames is designed to work completely offline, making it perfect for shooting in remote locations without internet connectivity. All your data is stored locally on your device, so you can log shots, manage your archive, and organize your gear anywhere. GPS location tagging also works offline and will be saved when you record each frame. The only time you need internet is when exporting metadata to scanned images or checking for app updates.

question8.question: What are the plans for future updates?
question8.answer: Future plans include expanding workflow features, improving integration across devices, and adding new tools requested by the community to make analog photography logging even more flexible and powerful.

meta.title: Privacy Policy - Frames
meta.description: Read the privacy policy for Frames, the analog photography notebook app. Learn how we handle your data with care on both mobile and desktop.

section1.heading: Introduction
section1.paragraph1: At Frames, your privacy is our priority. This Privacy Policy explains how we handle information across our iOS and macOS apps as well as our website. We are committed to keeping your data secure, transparent, and under your control. No unnecessary tracking or collection occurs, and you always remain in charge of the information you choose to share or export.

section2.heading: Frames for iOS and macOS
section2.paragraph1a: Frames does not collect, store, or share any personal data.
section2.paragraph1b: All information you enter in the app is stored locally on your device and never transmitted to any server or third party.
section2.paragraph2: The app uses Apple’s StoreKit framework to manage subscriptions. This process is handled entirely by Apple, and no personal information is accessible to the developer.
section2.paragraph3: Frames does not include analytics, tracking, or any online services. It makes no network connections except when using the system’s location service (CLLocationManager) to capture GPS coordinates if you choose to record them.
section2.paragraph4: When exporting data, the app may create .frames, .txt, or .gpx files. Sharing these files through the system share menu is entirely under your control. The developer does not access or track exported content.
section2.paragraph5: Frames requests the following system permissions:

line1.title: Camera
line1.description: to take a picture directly from the app.

line2.title: Photos
line2.description: to select reference images from your library.

line3.title: Location (While Using the App)
line3.description: to record your GPS coordinates when capturing frames.

section3.heading: withframes.com Website
section3.paragraph1a: The Frames website is a static site hosted on GitHub Pages.
section3.paragraph1b: It does not use cookies, analytics, or tracking scripts. No personal data is collected or stored.
section3.paragraph2: Cloudflare provides basic, anonymous traffic statistics based on server logs. These logs contain no personally identifiable information and are not used for profiling or marketing.
section3.paragraph3: The site includes outbound links to external websites and social media platforms for sharing content or acknowledging publications. Visiting those sites is optional and subject to their own privacy policies.
section3.paragraph4: No forms, newsletters, or interactive features collect information on this website.

section4.heading: Contacting us
section4.paragraph1: If you have any questions or concerns about this privacy policy, you can reach the developer at:
